Description: Rough vase of shale-tempered pink pottery with rounded point base, slightly convex sides and wide mouth with simple rim. Exterior discoloured by smoke and soot. Incised before firing on exterior beneath rim with deep potmark of two hatched squares.
Curator's comments: Potmark illustrated in W.M.F Petrie and A.C. Mace, Diospolis Parva, London (1901), pl. xxi.109. Most like R17C in Petrie’s Corpus of Prehistoric Pottery (1921). Shale tempered pottery is known in the early Naqada III period from a number of settlement sites (Elephantine, Hierakonpolis) and the vessels often carry pre-firing potmarks.
